content: I opened this thread looking for more reviews on the series of PR, and also for having this place for casual feedbacks. The linked PR is only a draft for rough preview, but it has a few dependent small PR ready for review.
:pleading_face:can I get some review?
Clarification: you are asking for reviews not of the PR mentioned in the title, but for #25190 and #25168 (for example).
cc @Scott Carnahan
yeah, I meant reviews for those small dependency PRs

I know -- but the first time I saw this thread I didn't even read what you wrote, I clicked on the link to go straight to #25140, saw it wasn't ready and then went on to something else. It was only when you pinged that I realised what you were actually asking!
Ah, sorry for causing confusion
Let me see how I can make this clearer when I get back to this

Here is the status of PRs after clean up & migrations:

#25168 & #25144: merged

#25970 further development about HahnSeries based on the previous two: ready for review

#26059 Q module on divisible group: ready for review

#26114 Embedding archimedean group into real: ready for review
I also have a small PR #26179 related to this
Bumping this to get more attention and reviews:grimacing:
Sorry, I got occupied with non-Lean duties. I should be able to review later this week.
Thanks!
@Scott Carnahan Got time to review it?
Another small PR #26513 (+7 -0) to add missing lemma
Created another two small PRs:
#26773
#26756
Thanks for the review! I figured it might be better to chop my PR into small pieces. So here are some more:
#26787 Add apply lemma for withTopCongr/withBotCongr (+6)
#26788 simp lemma for applying OrderIso.ofHomInv (+8)
#26789 (still somewhat large, +160) more tools for ArchimedeanClass
@Ruben Van de Velde Do you think the new approach of #26787 is fine?
#26787 is now a different approach to fix the underlying problem (still small though!)

Thanks for all the review again. Now #25970 (+368 −2) is on the critical path. I didn't separate MulArchimedeanClass₁ from HahnSeries lemmas because @Yaël Dillies would like to see a use case of the former. Hope this is a convincing one :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
Meanwhile, here are another two small PRs:
#27054 (+10) lemmas about LinearPMap.sSup domain
#27055 (+31) truncate map for HahnSeries (not sure if we want this or I should make it private)
Another little bump hoping these can get reviewed soon. I understand mathlib doesn't get enough reviewers, and I have been trying helping with reviews, though it has been pretty hard for me...
Apologies, this is the sort of stuff I would review, but I'm very busy until the 5th of August. If things haven't moved on your PR by then, feel free to request my review
No problem!
I've reviewed #26114, and it looks good to me now (but some of the theorems I suggested may have bad names). Could a maintainer or reviewer look at it please?
Thanks! I left one comment, and gave a bors d+
Thanks! Can I get another review of #27055 as well?
Also opened a small #27495 (+24 -0) for a few small lemma about Rat
Another small one #27501 (+12 −0) that's not really a dependency but discovered while I was exploring stuff
I have reviewed #27055 and it looks good to me.
:thinking:#27495 has been in bors queue for 3 hours... did it get stuck?
#bors doesn't show it, so I believe so
:sweat_smile:I don't have access to that page
Looks like bors crashed a few hours ago. Thanks for pointing this out!
I added a comment in #27055 about the open Classical in approach.

Thanks for calling it out, and I agree. I think I have it originally because there are other open Classical in the file such as HahnSeries.single. I guess by the same argument single should use DecidableEq instead?

yeah I would also be nervous about HahnSeries.single. This is the way we coded with Finsets in 2018 and it didn't end well. Open Classical is fine in proofs but one should be wary of it in definitions. Sorry to only respond now, I've been away for two weeks and I haven't caught up on Zulip. Maybe ask in #mathlib4 if you want a second opinion -- I am not an expert on decidability.
here is another small-ish one #27711 (+75 -21) that just adds boilerplates for Lex type
Opened #27885 (+339) to setup "balls" and "grades" (better name suggestions are welcome) in preparation for the main part of the theorem. Somewhat large but mostly just easy lemmas.

@Yaël Dillies as previously promised, I'd like your help on reviewing these:grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:. Here is a list of PRs ready for review:
Two large ones: #27885,#25970
Two small ones: #27055 (thanks for already taking a look) #27711
Sorry, I first need to find time to understand the paper proof of the Hahn embedding theorem :sweat:
No problem! I also have the draft formalization in #27043 as a reference
Here is another small PR #28136 (+46) add HahnSeries.ofFinsupp
I've looked at #28136 and it seems fine. In fact, I had been planning a similar contribution for my own purposes.
Can I get a possibly quick maintainer review on #28394? I'd like to move forward with further PRs that depends on it

After all the preparation, here comes the main course: #27043 (+1192). I can divide this into smaller ones upon requests, but because most of it is part of one proof, I'd like to give a view to the big picture.

I'd like to request for suggestions for naming a concept used in #27043: the module complement between ArchimedeanClass.ball (analogy: open ball in a valuation Valuation.ltAddSubgroup) and ArchimedeanClass.closedBall (analogy: closed ball in a valuation) with type ArchimedeanClass M → Submodule K M The proposal in the code is grade currently, but we don't really like it.
Some other ideas I have considered (all under the namespace HahnEmbeddingSeed):

  • single, monomial: they are the preimage of HahnSeries monomial under Hahn embedding
  • component, summand: if ArchimedeanClass M is finite, M is a direct sum of these components
  • subspace, submodule: don't be fancy. Just use the type name
  • section, "graded piece", "graded component" : suggested by LLM.
  • sphere: not really correct because this is not set complement
I chose leSubmodule and ltSubmodule in #26829
Another option, if I understand the similarity to another term, would be granule, and the whole indexed family is a granulation
But that's not exactly right since your submodules aren't a partition
That's a fun word I learned today
ballComplementModule? homogeneousSection?
maybe ballComplement is good enough

btw I'd also like to see @Violeta Hernández 's #28179 to get merged. It is currently in maintainer-merge queue. It is not on my dependency path, but I'd like to play around with it and see if I can eventually develop it into the field version of Hahn embedding theorem. (my excuse for not just merging it locally is that somehow I always get conflict when I try to do that, so I hope the merge bot can help me)

While the large #27043 is being reviewed, I have (re-)started another PR thread #29275 about DivisibleHull (currently with a leaf PR at #29277), which will be the last ingredient to complete the proof
Currently leaving some reviews.

Weiyi Wang said:

maybe ballComplement is good enough

I really don't like this. Mathlib uses the word "complement" to mean the complement with respect to some top element. What you have is more akin to a difference operator, except it's not that either!
I liked the grade suggestion. It gives the correct idea that your submodules stratify the group according to some function (the archimedean class).
If that doesn't work, may I suggest degree? Every submodule corresponds to an exponent in the Hahn series.
degree should refer to the ArchimedeanClass itself, not the whole term. I suggested "monomial/single" following this idea
single works for me

@Yaël Dillies what do you think?
"single" doesn't quite work in the structure name, though...
What if I call the structure ArchimedeanStrata, and the submodule is just a "stratum"
I like that too.
Sure
(sorry, I'm unavailable for the next week or so

I have renamed it to stratum and applied suggestion to move everything to a namespace. I haven't come up with an improvement for the DirectSum part yet, but feel free to review other sections of the proof, which don't depend on the implementation detail of baseEmbedding

Regarding #29275, the divisible hull can be defined for cancellative AddCommMonoids, not just AddCommGroups. In the torsion-free case, this amounts to tensoring with NNRat over Nat. I don't know whether it is better to generalize now or later.

If I understand correctly... if I want to generalize this while still staying with LocalizedModule, I would need

  • create IsLocalization (nonZeroDivisors ℕ) NNRat
  • use DivisibleHull M := LocalizedModule (nonZeroDivisors ℕ) M, which comes with Module NNRat (DivisibleHull M)
  • Then show Module Rat (DivisibleHull M) for group M?

Sounds like something I can try
Alright, so I made the generalization work and posted to a second file in #29275. Please let me know if I should keep working on the generalized version
I think the module approach is better. Instead of using mk x s for division, you can use the ℚ-smul instance, which seems much more elegant.

Violeta Hernández said:

I think the module approach is better. Instead of using mk x s for division, you can use the ℚ-smul instance, which seems much more elegant.

Both approaches in the PR uses LocalizedModule and becomes Module ℚ for group M. The difference is that LocalizedModule with Submonoid.pos \Z naturally comes with Module ℚ, but for LocalizedModule with nonZeroDivisors \N I need to manually define it
btw, here is a short generalization PR: #29386
And another short one #29388 for IsLocalization (nonZeroDivisors ℕ) ℚ≥0

Weiyi Wang said:

Violeta Hernández said:

I think the module approach is better. Instead of using mk x s for division, you can use the ℚ-smul instance, which seems much more elegant.

Both approaches in the PR uses LocalizedModule and becomes Module ℚ for group M. The difference is that LocalizedModule with Submonoid.pos \Z naturally comes with Module ℚ, but for LocalizedModule with nonZeroDivisors \N I need to manually define it

These two approaches are the same in the case of a group, right? Do you lose out on anything by just using the former?

In the case of a group, the end results are the same. I don't lose anything for my own use for just doing the former. The second approach was developed in response to @Scott Carnahan's suggestion for generalizing it
I don't really know which is better. I think it boils down to "should the divisible hull have scalar multiplication by non-negative rationals, or all rationals"?
I think I like the second version more since it is a generalization, and having positive number (instead of non-zero number) in the denominator is more justifiable there
It definitely feels nicer. If anyone needs the other version at some point we can split it out, or something.

As I am cleaning up divisible hull and stuff, here is a list of small PRs

  • #29421 Hahn.embDomain lemmas
  • #29423 ball ≤ .closedBall
  • #29451 FiniteArchimedeanClass equivalence from ArhcimedeanClass equivalence
  • #29388 NNRat is localization of Nat
  • #29386 Generalize IsMulTorsionFree on ordered monoid

:hooray: Small PRs are all merged. Now it is really just three big chunks remaining
#29275 (DivisibleHull) + #27043 (Embedding for module) -> #27268 (The full theorem)

I have put the DivisibleHull PR ready for review, though this one still has possibly large design decision to make

  • Should we use \N+ (or (n : \N, n \ne 0)) throughout the public API, or just nonZeroDivisors \N? I personally don't want to do \N+ as it is just more conversion work without much benefit, but if there are good arguments, I can change it
  • The underlying LocalizedModule is possibly going through a refactor (#25662). Any concerns about building new things on top of it?
I vote for ℕ+, or perhaps just ℕ with the n ≠ 0 assumption inserted where needed. I find nonZeroDivisors ℕ to be a really awkward spelling for what's essentially just "non-zero natural numbers".
In my opinion, we should keep nonZeroDivisors as an implementation detail.
hmm, I wonder if I could prove (nonZerDivisors N) and N+ are equal as types and just do cast. Hopefully it won't make it cursed
Nono
That's not going to work out

You miiiight be able to prove this (assuming both are implemented as a Subtype) but
a) this is implementation dependent
b) casts are awful
c) it's simple enough to just write the explicit equivalence wherever needed

Weiyi Wang said:

hmm, I wonder if I could prove (nonZerDivisors N) and N+ are equal as types and just do cast. Hopefully it won't make it cursed

they are equal as types but it does make it cursed
also an implementation detail
if someone changes the definition of PNat to be a structure then it will not be possible to prove them equal as types
:smile:Glad to discard a cursed idea first
how about building a ↥(nonZeroDivisors ℕ) ≃* ℕ+
Do we really need this
yeah that would be my next idea
Again, the conversion should be straightforward to do manually
And presumably only needed for the most basic defs/theorems
I tried it once and got frastruated... I can try again
Alright, I have switched over to PNat. In the end you are probably right that I likely don't need the equiv, but I find it nice to have in general so I still put it there
I'd like to get maintainer review for #29275. Sorry for being impatient for the last bit of the theorem...
(gentle nudge as it has been in the maintainer queue for a week)
While #29275 is waiting for review, I figured I can separate out some remaining bits for quick review. Here is a short one: #30101

Perhaps I should ask for the estimated time for #29275 so I don't blindly wait for it. I noticed there are a few other older PR ready in the maintainer queue (I am totally fine if they are dealt with first) but it seems they are not moving forward either. It would be great to know if the queue is generally waiting on something and how long I should expect

The wait time depends entirely on how much time the maintainers have, or more precisely, the subset of maintainers who feel qualified to do a final check on material in this subject area. This is, I think, more or less unknowable, since many of them have obligations outside the world of maintaining Mathlib that can vary with time.

I'll have a look at the last part of #25140 soon.
Thanks! I guess I'll just be more patient then, and try helping with other review when it is within my knowledge
Thanks for the review! The last part #27268 is now ready. It is only 50 lines of real code and a bunch of doc

@Judith Ludwig and I are developing valuation theory and we started with convex subgroups (also called "isolated subgroups" e.g. in Wikipedia) in linearly ordered (LO) groups. The height (or rank) of an LO group is defined to be the number of convex subgroups in the literature, though I think it's more naturally to define it as the number of Finite(Mul)ArchimedeanClasses. We've already constructed the OrderIso (ConvexSubgroup α)ᵒᵈ ≃o UpperSet (FiniteMulArchimedeanClass α), from which it's clear ConvexSubgroup α and FiniteMulArchimedeanClass α have the same cardinality if one of them is finite. (We have to use OrderDual and UpperSet instead of LowerSet, and feel that the order on FiniteMulArchimedeanClass may be more natural if reversed.)

An immediate goal is to show an LO group has rank at most 1 if it embeds into the reals. I wonder if anyone has shown that Archimedean G is equivalent to Subsingleton (FiniteArchimedeanClass G), and that HahnSeries Γ R is isomorphic to R if Γ is a singleton? It might be an overkill, but once we have these we can use hahnEmbedding_isOrderedAddMonoid to conclude.
I thought that was in a PR of @Weiyi Wang that I reviewed, but I might be wrong
I've found one direction which is FiniteArchimedeanClass.instSubsingletonOfAddArchimedean
Oh I've also found Archimedean.embedReal, which comes from #26114

The PR description says it's a special case of Hahn embedding, which is true, but apparently it's used to prove Hahn embedding ... anyway Archimedean.exists_orderAddMonoidHom_real_injective should be good enough for our purpose.
Having the opposite order on archimedean classes would certainly make them a bit more intuitive in my opinion, but I don't mind too much either way.

@Junyan Xu I suspect ConvexSubgroup is the docs#ArchimedeanClass.addSubgroup I introduced when proving Hahn embedding theorem. Feel free to rename it as I wasn't aware of the standard name of it in literature

I wonder if anyone has shown that Archimedean G is equivalent to Subsingleton (FiniteArchimedeanClass G)

docs#FiniteArchimedeanClass.instSubsingletonOfAddArchimedean for one direction. docs#ArchimedeanClass.archimedean_of_mk_eq_mk for the other (I didn't add the FiniteArchimedeanClass version, so feel free to add)

and yeah if this is an Archimedean group, docs#Archimedean.exists_orderAddMonoidHom_real_injective is enough

About the ordering, I chose the order based on the first few literature I read, but it is certainly debatable (in a similar way Valuation and AddValuation have opposite order), so I won't mind it if we decide to flip the direction.
Nice! I think docs#ArchimedeanClass.addSubgroup is our UpperSet.finiteMulArchimedeanClassToSubgroup except it's using ArchimedeanClass without "Finite".

Great!
Another reason for introducing convex subgroup (besides defining the height) is that if you want to take a quotient of a linear ordered comm group and get a linear ordered group, convexity is the condition that allows you to install a linear order on the quotient. So I think it is good to have it as a predicate on subgroups. It can be defined as

variable {α : Type*} [CommGroup α] [LinearOrder α]
def IsConvexSubgroup (H : Subgroup α) : Prop :=
  ∀ ⦃a b : α⦄, (a ≤ b) → (b ≤ 1) → a ∈ H → b ∈ H
Is this any different to docs#Set.OrdConnected ? Certainly, OrdConnected H \r IsConvexSubgroup H, but I couldn't quickly convince myself that the other implication holds
Oh yes of course it does. If a \in H and 1 \le a, then a\^-1 \in H and a \^-1 \le 1, so you are in the happy place again
Indeed! I didn't recognize that the equivalent characterization iff_mem_of_le_of_le can be spelt using OrdConnected.
speaking of installing linear order on the quotient, you probably like #29735
